page.title: 04LIVING IN AN OAST HOUSE
page.content: Hops for beer making are dried in an Oast House. Fewer hops are grown now so many of these houses have been converted into dwellings. My house, built in 1830 and converted in about 1915, consists of a roundel and a square part. A winding staircase carries you up to three floors in the roundel. Dormer windows project from circular walls and the tiled kiln, on top of which used to stand a wooden cowl, open one side. The house faces south and west, overlooking farmland. The walls in the roundel, 19" thick, are made of Kentish Ragstone and Flint. The rooms are warm in winter and cool in summer. The bathroom is a section taken out of the first floor round bedroom and the kitchen is a modern addition, built in 1954. We have some difficulty trying to arrange furniture in a round room.
